questions.text: Injury to the nerve marked by the red arrow in the given image results in loss of which of the following sensations of the tongue?
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the lingual nerve. Injury to the lingual nerve results in loss of general sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

Points of identification: The nerve runs downwards and forwards on the surface of the medial pterygoid muscle.

In the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, general sensations are carried by the lingual nerve, and the taste sensation is carried by the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve.

In the posterior one-third of the tongue, both general and taste sensations are carried by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Hypoglossal nerve innervates all the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue except for palatoglossus, which is supplied by the vagus nerve.

Valleculae are supplied by the internal laryngeal branch of the vagus nerve.

Related Pearl: Sensory Innervation of Tongue

Area

General sensory

Special sensory

Anterior 2/3rds

Lingual nerve (CN V)

Chorda tympani (CN VII)

Posterior 1/3rd

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Posterior most tongue (vallecullae, epiglottis)

Internal laryngeal nerve (CN X)

Internal laryngeal nerve (CN X)

questions.text: Foramen ovale is located in which part of the skull bone?
questions.solution:
Foramen ovale is found in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone which is marked as 1 in the above image.

Opening in Skull Bone of Skull Structures Transmitted
Anterior Cranial Fossa

Perforations in the cribriform plate

 Ethmoid Olfactory nerves

Middle Cranial Fossa

Optic canal

Lesser wing of the sphenoid

The optic nerve, ophthalmic artery

Superior orbital fissure    

Between lesser and greater wings of the sphenoid

Lacrimal, frontal, trochlear, oculomotor, nasociliary, and abducent nerves; superior ophthalmic vein 

Foramen rotundum

Greater wing of the sphenoid

The maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve

Foramen ovale

Greater wing of the sphenoid

Mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, lesser petrosal nerve 

Foramen spinosum

Greater wing of the sphenoid

Middle meningeal artery  

Foramen lacerum

Between the petrous part of temporal and sphenoid

Deep petrosal nerve and some meningeal arterial branches and small veins

Posterior Cranial Fossa
Foramen magnum  Occipital Medulla oblongata, spinal part of accessory nerve, and right and left vertebral arteries
Hypoglossal canal Occipital  Hypoglossal nerve
 Jugular foramen Between the petrous part of temporal and condylar part of occipital Glossopharyngeal, vagus, and accessory nerves; sigmoid sinus becomes an internal jugular vein

Internal acoustic meatus   

Petrous part of temporal

Vestibulocochlear and facial nerves

questions.text: The muscles semimembranosus and semitendinosus arise from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Semimembranosus and semitendinosus arise from the ischial tuberosity which is marked as "B" in the above image.

The ischial tuberosity is broadly divided into an upper and lower area.

  • The upper area is further subdivided into a superolateral part for semimembranosus and an inferomedial part for the long head of biceps femoris and the semitendinosus.
  • The lower area is subdivided by an irregular vertical ridge, into lateral and medial areas. The larger lateral area is for the adductor magnus. The smaller medial area is covered by adipose tissue, which usually contains the sciatic bursa of the gluteus maximus, which supports the body in sitting.

questions.text: A buried skeleton was brought to the forensic laboratory. Age estimation was carried out. With respect to the carpal bones shown below, which among them are the first and last bones to ossify, respectively?
questions.solution:
The capitate (marked as 5) is the first one to ossify and the pisiform (marked as 3) is the last carpal bone to ossify.

Order of ossification centers of carpal bones:

  • Capitate: 1-3 months
  • Hamate: 2-4 months
  • Triquetrum: 2-3 years
  • Lunate: 2-4 years
  • Scaphoid: 4-6 years
  • Trapezium: 4-6 years
  • Trapezoid: 4-6 years
  • Pisiform: 8-12 years

At the end of 1 year, 2 carpal bones are seen in the x-ray of the wrist. Between 2 to 6 years the number of carpal bones present on x-ray indicates the approximate age in years. 

The capitate is the central and largest carpal bone. It articulates with the following:

  • 2nd, 3rd and 4th metacarpal
  • Lunate and scaphoid in the proximal row 
  • Trapezoid and hamate in the distal row

Pisiform articulates with triquetrum.

questions.text: In the given image showing the dorsal aspect of the hand, identify the nerve supply of the structure marked as A:

choices.text: Radial nerve before division into superficial and deep branches
Deep branch of radial nerve before penetrating supinator muscle

questions.solution:
The structure labeled as A is the tendon of the extensor digitorum and it is supplied by the posterior interosseous nerve. It can be identified as it divides into four tendons which then diverge on the back of the hand, and are inserted into the middle and distal phalanges of the fingers.

It mainly extends the index, middle, ring, and little fingers and also extends the wrist.

Radial nerve before division (C5, C6)
  • Brachioradialis
  • Extensor carpi radialis longus (ECRL)

Radial nerve deep branch before penetrating supinator (C7, C8)
  • Extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB)

Posterior interosseous nerve (C7, C8)
  • Superficial
    • Extensor digitorum
    • Extensor digiti minimi (EDM)
    • Extensor carpi ulnaris (ECU)
  • Deep
    • Supinator
    • Abductor pollicis longus (APL)
    • Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)
    • Extensor pollicis longus (EPL)
    • Extensor indicis

Radial nerve

(C6,C7,C8)
  • Anconeus

The deep branch of radial nerve after penetrating supinator is called posterior interosseous nerve.

questions.text: The muscle marked as X in the image given below has its origin from the lateral epicondyle and it forms the most medial part of the common extensor origin. This muscle is:
questions.solution:
The muscle marked as X is extensor carpi ulnaris, and it arises from the lateral epicondyle, the posterior border of the ulna, and overlying fascia. It forms the most medial part of the common extensor origin.

It forms a tendon in the distal third of the forearm that slides in a groove between the head and the styloid process of the ulna.

It extends and adducts the wrist. It receives its innervation from the posterior interosseous nerve.

Identification hint: Extensor digitorum forms the lateral relation to extensor carpi ulnaris.

 

Other options:

  • Anconeus causes abduction of the ulna in pronation.
  • Extensor carpi radialis longus together with extensor carpi radialis brevis produce wrist extension and abduction (radial deviation).
  • Extensor digitorum mainly extends the index, middle, ring, and little fingers and also extends the wrist.

questions.text: A 22-year-old boy who recently had his femur operated after a road traffic accident develops sudden onset of chest pain and difficulty in breathing. His x-ray showed Hampton's hump and Westermark sign. Which of the following marked structure is affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the X-ray showing Hampton's hump and Westermark sign are suggestive of pulmonary embolism. This occurs due to clot in the pulmonary artery which is marked as 'A' in the above image. It can be identified as it arises from the right ventricle.

Pulmonary embolism refers to embolic occlusion of the pulmonary arterial system. Most patients present with pleuritic chest pain, dyspnoea, and tachypnoea. The classical clinical triad of sudden onset of chest pain, dyspnoea, and hemoptysis is present in only a few cases.

Chest X-ray signs related to pulmonary embolism include:

  • Hampton's hump is a pleural based, wedge-shaped opacity with the apex of the triangle pointed towards the occluding vessel or hilum and implies lung infarction. 
  • Westermark sign is a chest X-ray finding in pulmonary embolism. It is defined by a hyper lucent area with decreased vascularity due to oligemia of the involved part of the lung.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text: The fornix ends in which structure of the floor of the third ventricle?
questions.solution:
The fornix arises from the hippocampus and ends in the mamillary body of the hypothalamus which is marked as 'A' in the given image.

The mammillary bodies are smooth, hemispherical, pea-sized eminences, lying side by side, anterior to the posterior perforated substance, each with nuclei enclosed in fascicles of fibers derived largely from the fornix.

The fornix is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery.

Related Pearl: Boundaries of the 3rd ventricle

Roof: Choroid plexus

Lateral wall:

  • Thalamus
  • Hypothalamus

Anterior wall: 

  • Anterior commissure
  • Lamina terminalis

Posterior wall: 

  • Pineal gland
  • Posterior commissure
  • Aqueduct of Sylvius

Floor: 

  • Optic chiasma
  • Infundibulum
  • Mamillary bodies
  • Posterior perforating substance
  • Tegmentum of midbrain

questions.text: The structure marked as '?' in the image below connects which of the following two ventricles?

choices.text: Third ventricle with the lateral ventricles
Third ventricle with the fourth ventricle
Lateral ventricle with the fourth ventricle

questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above image is the cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius which connects the third ventricle with the fourth ventricle.

The cerebral aqueduct is a small, approximately circular tube with a diameter of 1-2 mm. It runs along the midline of the dorsal quarter of the midbrain, surrounded by the periaqueductal (central) grey matter. At the rostral end, it starts just below the posterior commissure and connects to the caudal aspect of the third ventricle. At the caudal end, it continues into the fourth ventricle, located at the junction of the midbrain and pons. In children with von Recklinghausen's disease, primary aqueductal stenosis is a characteristic feature.

 

Other options:

Option A - The third ventricle is connected to the lateral ventricles via the interventricular foramina of Monro on either side.

questions.text: Identify the sulcus marked as A in the image below.
questions.solution:
The sulcus marked in the above image is the prechiasmatic sulcus.

The pre-chiasmatic sulcus (also called chiasmatic groove or optic groove) is a transverse groove in the sphenoid bone, between the optic canals. The optic chiasma lies over the pre-chiasmatic sulcus.

 

Option A: The sigmoid sulcus is a wide groove, present anteriorly, in the mastoid part of the temporal bone.

 

Option B: Carotid sulcus is a shallow groove in the lateral wall of the body of the sphenoid. It contains the internal carotid artery.

Option C: Transverse sulcus is the groove for the transverse sinus in the occipital bone, as shown below.

questions.text: The medial boundary of the femoral triangle is formed by the medial border of which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
The medial boundary of the femoral triangle is formed by the medial margin of adductor longus which is marked as "D" in the above image.

The lateral boundary of the femoral triangle is formed by the medial margin of the sartorius.

Related Pearl: Femoral Triangle

The femoral triangle is a depressed, intermuscular space present in the anteromedial aspect of the proximal thigh.

Boundaries of Femoral triangle are:

Medially- Medial border of Adductor longus

Laterally- Medial border of Sartorius

Base- Inguinal ligament

Floor (lateral to medial)- Iliacus, Psoas major, Pectineus, Adductor longus

Roof- Skin, Superficial fascia, Fascia lata, superficial branches of femoral vessels–superficial epigastric, superficial external pudendal, superficial circumflex iliac vessels and GSV. 

Note: Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve which forms a content of the triangle also forms its roof as it pierces the fascia to supply the skin over the triangle. 

Contents:

  • Femoral sheath containing lymph node of Cloquet, femoral vein, femoral artery, femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve.
  • Femoral nerve and its branches
  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of thigh

questions.text: A 65 years old male patient with a history of hypertension presented with an intracranial hemorrhage due to the rupture of the Charcot's artery. This artery is a striate branch of which of the following marked structure?
questions.solution:
Charcot's artery is the striate branch of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) which is marked as C in the above image. 

A- Superior cerebellar artery 

B- Posterior cerebral artery

C- Middle cerebral artery (MCA)

D- Anterior cerebral artery

 

The MCA arises from the internal carotid artery as the larger one of the two main terminal branches (the other being the anterior cerebral artery). Striate arteries are the small diameter branches of the MCA (and anterior cerebral artery) which penetrate into the cerebrum and supply the deeper structures.

Charcot-Bouchard aneurysms located in the lenticulostriate vessels of the basal ganglia are commonly associated with hypertension. Charcot's artery supplies the internal capsule and basal ganglia. It is also known as the 'Charcot's artery of cerebral hemorrhage'. 

Related Pearl: Arteries supplying specific parts of the brain

Parts of Brain Arteries supplying it
Basal ganglia
  • Lateral striate artery - a branch of MCA
  • Medial striate artery - a branch of ACA
  • Anterior and posterior  choroidal arteries
  • Thalamogeniculate branch of PCA
Internal capsule
  • Lateral striate artery - a branch of MCA
  • Medial striate artery (Recurrent artery of Heubner) - a branch of ACA
  • Anterior choroidal artery - a branch of ICA
Thalamus
  • Posterior communicating arteries
  • Posterior cerebral arteries
  • Basilar artery
Midbrain
  • Posterior cerebral arteries
  • Superior cerebellar arteries
  • Basilar artery
Pons
  • Basilar artery
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • Superior cerebellar arteries.
Medulla oblongata
  • Vertebral artery
  • Anterior and posterior spinal arteries
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar arteries
  • Basilar artery
Cerebellum
  • Superior cerebellar arteries
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar arteries
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar arteries

 

ACA - Anterior cerebral artery

MCA- Middle cerebral artery

PCA - Posterior cerebral artery

ICA - Internal carotid artery

Related Pearl: Blood supply of Brain

The brain is supplied by Internal Carotid arteries and Vertebrobasilar arteries. 

Areas supplied by various arteries
Anterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves around the corpus callosum within the sagittal fissure

Supply - Dorsomedial frontal and parietal lobes

Effects of occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA): 

- Contralateral Paralysis (or weakness) of muscles of the leg and foot - Upper part of motor area affected.

- Contralateral Loss (or dulling) of sensations from the leg and foot - Upper part of the sensory area affected.
Middle Cerebral Artery

Course - Runs within Sylvian fissure

Supply - Lateral convexity of the cerebral cortex

Effects of occlusion of middle cerebral artery (MCA):

- Contralateral Hemiplegia -  loss of sensations. The face and arms are most affected, foot and leg are spared.  

- Aphasia - Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas affected, especially if the thrombosis is in the left hemisphere in a right-handed person.  

- Contralateral Homonymous hemianopia - due to the involvement of optic radiation.  
Posterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves behind the midbrain

Supply - Occipital lobe and inferior and medial temporal lobe

Effects of occlusion of posterior cerebral artery (PCA):

- Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing - Affected Cortical blood supply > Damage to association cortex of visual area causes visual hallucinations (distortion of colour vision).

Note: Macular sparing is due to collateral circulation from MCA to that cortical region. 

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: The given image shows the vasculature of the abdomen. Which of the following labeled structures in the image gives rise to the deep circumflex iliac artery?
questions.solution:
The deep circumflex iliac artery branches laterally from the external iliac artery which is marked as 'B' in the given image. 

The external iliac artery is the main artery of the lower limb. Its branches include:

  • Deep circumﬂex iliac artery
  • Inferior epigastric artery
  • Small branches to psoas major and nearby lymph nodes
  • Continues into the thigh as the femoral artery

Related Pearl: The circle of death/Crown of death/Corona mortis:

  • It is a vascular continuation formed by the common iliac, internal iliac, obturator, inferior epigastric, and external iliac vessels.
  • Accessory obturator artery which is a branch of inferior epigastric artery, arches over Cooper’s ligament and joins the normal obturator artery and forms a complete vascular ring.
  • Injury leads to torrential haemorrhage which is difficult to control.

questions.text: Which is the only rotator cuff muscle innervated by the axillary nerve?
questions.solution:
The rotator cuff is a group of four muscles that have common features regarding their origin (from the scapula) and insertion (into lesser and greater tubercles of the humerus). Of the four muscles, the teres minor, marked as '4', is the only rotator cuff muscle innervated by the axillary nerve.

Teres minor originates from the upper two-thirds of the lateral border of the scapula on the dorsal surface. It inserts into the lowermost impression of the greater tubercle on the humerus. 

Rotator cuff muscles:

The rotator cuff is a group of 4 muscles (SITS) that stabilizes the shoulder joint:

Muscle Insertion Innervation
S: Supraspinatus Greater tubercle Suprascapular nerve
I: Infraspinatus Greater tubercle Suprascapular nerve 
T: Teres Minor Greater tubercle Axillary nerve
S: Subscapularis Lesser tubercle Upper and Lower subscapular nerve 

 

Clinical correlate - Shoulder impingement syndrome, also called subacromial impingement syndrome, is a clinical condition that occurs when the upper surface of the rotator cuff tendons becomes impinged under the coracoacromial arch.

 

The other marked structures in the cadaveric specimen shown are muscles that do not belong to the rotator cuff:

1 - Deltoid (supplied by the axillary nerve)

2 - Long head of triceps brachii (supplied by the radial nerve)

3 - Teres major (supplied by the lower subscapular nerve)

questions.text: The acute inflammation of which of the following structure is responsible for the appearance of thumb sign on the lateral x-ray of the neck?
questions.solution:
The thumb sign on the lateral X-ray of the neck is usually seen in acute epiglottitis. The epiglottis is labeled as 'B' in the above image.

Acute epiglottitis is an acute rapidly progressive and potentially fulminating course of high fever, sore throat, dyspnea, and rapidly progressing respiratory obstruction.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: Which of the following marked structure is best seen in Caldwell's view?
questions.solution:
The frontal sinus is best seen in Caldwell's view and it is marked as 'B' in the above image.

Structures seen in Caldwell's view are:

  • Frontal sinuses (seen best)
  • Ethmoid sinuses
  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone
  • Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)

 

The X-ray view shown in the image below is the Caldwell view.

  • The nose and forehead are touching the x-ray film
  • The X-ray beam is projected 15 degrees caudally

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

questions.text: Identify the extensor digiti minimi tendon.
questions.solution:
The structure 'A' is the extensor digiti minimi tendon.

The extensor digiti minimi tendon is medial to the tendon of extensor digitorum (marked as C). It is innervated by the posterior interosseous nerve, C7 and 8.

Extensor digiti minimi extends all the joints of the little finger and also contributes to wrist extension. It permits extension of the little finger independent of the extension of the other digits.

questions.text: The image below shows anterior dissection of the neck in a cadaver. Stimulation of which of the following marked structure will lead to inhibition of the AV node?
questions.solution:
Stimulation of the left vagus nerve which is marked as 'B' in the above image will lead to inhibition of the AV node.

Other structures:

A - Right Vagus Nerve

C - Recurrent laryngeal nerve

D - Right Phrenic nerve

Related Pearl: Effect of the Autonomic Nervous System on Heart

ANS

Effects

Right vagus

Inhibits SA node

Decreases the heart rate

Left vagus

Inhibits AV node

Slow AV conduction

Right Stellate ganglion

Stimulates SA node

Increases the heart rate

Left stellate ganglion

Stimulate AV node

Shortened AV conduction time

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not supplied by the structure marked by the red arrow in the given image?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the musculocutaneous nerve. It does not supply triceps brachii muscle.

The structure can be identified as a musculocutaneous nerve as it pierces the coracobrachialis muscle in its course and also supplies the biceps brachii. The root value of the musculocutaneous nerve is C5, C6, C7.

The musculocutaneous nerve supplies all the muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm, which include coracobrachialis, brachialis, and biceps brachii muscles.

Related Pearl: Brachial Plexus

Brachial Plexus

  • C5 to T1
  • Roots (from spinal cord) > Trunks (in the neck)> Divisions (passing behind clavicle) > Cords and Branches (in the axilla).
  • Covered by prevertebral fascia extension called "axillary sheath"

Trunks:

  • Upper trunk: C5 and C6
  • Middle trunk: C7.
  • Lower trunk: C8 and T1

Divisions:

  • Anterior divisions - Forms lateral and medial cords supplying mainly flexors 
  • Posterior divisions - Forms posterior cord which suppy mainly extensors 

Cords:

  • Lateral cord: Formed by anterior divisions of the upper and middle trunks.
  • Posterior cord: Formed by all 3 posterior divisions 
  • Medial cord: Formed by anterior division of the lower trunk.

Branches: 

 Parts 

Branches
Roots

Dorsal scapular nerve (C5)

Long thoracic nerve of Bell (C5-C7)
Upper trunk

Suprascapular nerve (C5, C6)

Nerve to Subclavius (C5, C6).
Lateral cord (LML)

Lateral pectoral nerve (C5-C7)

Musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C7)

Lateral root of median nerve (C5-C7)
Medial cord (UM4)

Medial pectoral (C8,T1)

Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm (C8,T1)

Medial cutaneous nerve of arm (C8,T1)

Ulnar nerve (C8,T1)

Medial root of median nerve (C8,T1)
Posterior cord (STARS)

Upper Subscapular nerve (C5,C6)

Thoracodorsal nerve (C6-C8)

Axillary (C5,C6)

Radial (C5-T1)

Lower Subscapular (C5,C6)

 

Note : However Ulnar Nerve near its origin, often receives a communicating branch from the lateral root of the median nerve originating from the lateral cord and carrying fibers from C7.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the structure marked with the red arrow?

choices.text: Nerve supply to the skin of the upper eyelid and forehead
Divides into a medial supratrochlear nerve and lateral supraorbital nerve
Smallest branch of the ophthalmic nerve

questions.solution:
The marked structure is the frontal nerve and it is the largest branch of the ophthalmic nerve.

It can be identified as it passes forwards towards the rim of the orbit on the levator palpebrae superioris muscle.

The frontal nerve divides into a medial supratrochlear nerve and a lateral supraorbital nerve. These nerves end up supplying the conjunctiva and skin of the upper eyelid and forehead.

questions.text: Tennis leg occurs due to complete or partial tear of which of the following marked muscles?
questions.solution:
Tennis leg is a complete or partial tear of the medial head of the gastrocnemius muscle (marked as 'D' in the above image) at the distal musculotendinous junction.

The gastrocnemius is the most superficial muscle of the calf and is composed of 2 muscle heads. The medial head originates from the posterior medial femoral condyle and the lateral head originates from the posterior lateral femoral condyle.

The classic presentation is acute mid-calf pain in a middle-aged person. This is most often a sports-associated injury caused during extension of the knee and forced dorsiflexion of the ankle.

questions.text: Below is the image of the cubital fossa. Which of the following two marked structures are tested in the modified Allen's test before taking blood for arterial blood gas analysis?
questions.solution:
Modified Allen's test is useful in identifying the adequacy of radial (marked 'B') and ulnar (marked 'C') collateral blood flow to the hand. It is done prior to radial artery cannulation and drawing blood for ABG analysis.

Steps:

  • The patient is first asked to open and close their fist to help increase the draining of blood from the hand.
  • The ulnar and radial arteries are then compressed by the examiner simultaneously.
  • The hand should be pale now.
  • The compression is then released from the ulnar artery while maintaining pressure over the radial artery.
  • If the hand flushes, it means that the ulnar blood supply is intact.
  • This test is repeated in the same hand while releasing the radial artery first while continuing to compress the ulnar artery.

questions.text: The given image shows the popliteal fossa. All are innervated by the structure marked 'A' except ______.

choices.text: Muscles in the posterior compartment of the leg
Intrinsic muscles in the sole of the foot
Extensor digitorum brevis in the dorsal aspect of the foot
Skin on the posterolateral side of the lower half of the leg

questions.solution:
The structure marked as 'A' is the tibial nerve and it supplies all the above-mentioned structures except extensor digitorum brevis in the dorsal aspect of the foot which is supplied by the common fibular nerve.

In the popliteal fossa, the tibial nerve is lateral to the popliteal vessels. At the level of the knee, the tibial nerve becomes superficial to the popliteal vessels and crosses to the medial side of the popliteal artery.

Related Pearl: Various muscles of the leg and their innervation:

 

Muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg and dorsum of foot

Nerve Supply

Tibialis anterior

 

 

Deep Peroneal Nerve

Extensor hallucis longus

Extensor digitorum longus

Peroneus tertius

Extensor digitorum brevis

Muscles of the lateral component of the leg

 

Peroneus longus

 

Superficial Peroneal Nerve

Peroneus brevis

Superficial muscles of the posterior compartment of the leg

 

Gastrocnemius

 

Tibial Nerve

Soleus

Plantaris

Deep muscles of the posterior compartment of the leg

 

Popliteus

 

 

Tibial Nerve

Flexor digitorum longus

Flexor hallucis longus

Tibialis posterior

questions.text: A class is being conducted on the various structures present in the next. Neck dissection is performed, and the given image shows the lateral aspect of the neck. All of the following muscles are supplied by nerves arising from the structure 'A' and its branches, except _____.
questions.solution:
The structure marked as A in the above image is the inferior root of ansa cervicalis, and it supplies all the above-mentioned muscles, except the thyrohyoid.

The inferior root descends on the lateral side of the internal jugular vein, crosses it a little below the middle of the neck, and continues forwards to join the superior root anterior to the common carotid artery, forming the ansa cervicalis (ansa hypoglossi).

Ansa cervicalis: 

  • It is a loop of nerves that are a part of the cervical plexus. It is made up of two roots. The upper root has contributions from the first cervical spinal nerve, and the lower root has contributions from the second and third cervical spinal nerves.
  • It innervates sternohyoid, sternothyroid, and omohyoid muscles.

The thyrohyoid and geniohyoid are not supplied by ansa cervicalis. They are supplied by the first cervical spinal nerve, via the hypoglossal nerve.

questions.text: A middle-aged chronic smoker came to the hospital with back pain and continuous deep pain in the abdomen. On examination, a pulsating mass is felt in the abdomen. He is a known case of Marfan syndrome. Identify the structure responsible for the painful pulsating mass.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Marfan syndrome associated with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. In the above image, the vessel labeled as 'A' is the abdominal aorta, as it is situated just anterior to the vertebral column.

Abdominal aortic aneurysms are much more common than thoracic aneurysms and the most common location is the infra-renal aorta.

Marfan syndrome is a genetic condition that affects connective tissue. It is associated with aortic aneurysms.

questions.text: The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is mainly formed by __________.
questions.solution:
The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is mainly formed by the choroid plexus which is marked as 'B' in the above image.

Formation of CSF:

  • Major contributor: choroid plexuses of the lateral, third and fourth ventricles.
  • Minor contributors: Ependymal cells lining the ventricles, brain substance through the perivascular spaces.

Choroid plexus if the best answer as it is the main source of CSF formation.

questions.text: Which structure prevents the ascent of the horseshoe kidney?
questions.solution:
The inferior mesenteric artery (marked as C) prevents the ascent of the horseshoe kidney.

A- Femoral cutaneous nerve 

B- Right ureter

D- Left ureter

The inferior mesenteric artery branches off from the anterior surface of the abdominal aorta usually 3-4 cm above the aortic bifurcation at the L3 vertebral level.

Horseshoe kidney is caused due to the fusion of lower poles of the kidney and it's ascent is prevented by the inferior mesenteric artery. Hence they cannot reach the normal level of T12- L3 and found low lying, ususally in the lower abdomen. Horseshoe kidneys are prone to reflux, obstruction, and stone formation.

questions.text: The spinal part of the accessory nerve passes through _______.
questions.solution:
The spinal part of the accessory nerve passes through the foramen magnum marked as 'D' in the given image.

Related Pearl: Structures passing through skull foramina

Opening Transmits
Optic canal
  • Optic nerves
  • Ophthalmic arteries
Superior orbital fissure
  • Lacrimal nerve (V1)
  • Frontal nerve (V1)
  • Nasociliary nerve (V1)
  • CNs III, IV, VI
  • Superior ophthalmic vein
  • Inferior ophthalmic vein
Foramen rotundum
  • Maxillary division of CN V (V2)
Foramen ovale
  • Mandibular division of CN V (V3)
  • Accessory meningeal artery
  • Lesser petrosal nerve
  • Emissary veins
Foramen spinosum
  • Middle meningeal artery
  • Nervus spinosus
  • Middle meningeal vein
Foramen lacerum
  • Deep petrosal nerve
  • Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery 
  • Emissary vein
Carotid canal
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Venous and sympathetic plexus around artery
Jugular foramen
  • Inferior petrosal sinus
  • Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery 
  • CNs IX,X & XI
  • Sigmoid Sinus continuing as IJV 
  • Middle meningeal branch of occipital artery
Hypoglossal canal
  • Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII)
Foramen magnum
  • Osseo-ligamentous (anterior) compartment: 
    • Apical ligament and tip of dens
    • Upper band of cruciate ligament
    • Membrana tectoria
  • Neuro-vascular (posterior) compartment:
    • Lower end of the medulla oblongata with meninges
    • Fourth part of vertebral artery surrounded by sympathetic plexus of nerves
    • Spinal roots of accessory nerves
    • Anterior and posterior spinal arteries
    • Tonsil of cerebellum.

questions.text: A first-year student while dissecting through the brachial plexus in a cadaver accidentally cut the structure marked “X”.  Had the same mistake been done by a surgeon in neck surgery, all of the following nerves would have been affected except:
questions.solution:
The structure marked as 'X' in the above image is the lateral cord, and hence all the nerves arising from it will be affected if the cord would have been cut by a surgeon during neck surgery. The thoracodorsal nerve arises from the posterior cord so its function can't be impaired due to an injury to the lateral cord.

The lateral cord is identified because the marked structure is formed from the superior and middle trunk only.

The lateral pectoral nerve and musculocutaneous nerve arise from the lateral cord.

The ulnar nerve is a branch of the medial cord however, it receives the lateral root of the median nerve originating from the lateral cord.

Related Pearl: Brachial Plexus

Brachial Plexus

  • C5 to T1
  • Roots (from spinal cord) > Trunks (in the neck)> Divisions (passing behind clavicle) > Cords and Branches (in the axilla).
  • Covered by prevertebral fascia extension called "axillary sheath"

Trunks:

  • Upper trunk: C5 and C6
  • Middle trunk: C7.
  • Lower trunk: C8 and T1

Divisions:

  • Anterior divisions - Forms lateral and medial cords supplying mainly flexors 
  • Posterior divisions - Forms posterior cord which suppy mainly extensors 

Cords:

  • Lateral cord: Formed by anterior divisions of the upper and middle trunks.
  • Posterior cord: Formed by all 3 posterior divisions 
  • Medial cord: Formed by anterior division of the lower trunk.

Branches: 

 Parts 

Branches
Roots

Dorsal scapular nerve (C5)

Long thoracic nerve of Bell (C5-C7)
Upper trunk

Suprascapular nerve (C5, C6)

Nerve to Subclavius (C5, C6).
Lateral cord (LML)

Lateral pectoral nerve (C5-C7)

Musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C7)

Lateral root of median nerve (C5-C7)
Medial cord (UM4)

Medial pectoral (C8,T1)

Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm (C8,T1)

Medial cutaneous nerve of arm (C8,T1)

Ulnar nerve (C8,T1)

Medial root of median nerve (C8,T1)
Posterior cord (STARS)

Upper Subscapular nerve (C5,C6)

Thoracodorsal nerve (C6-C8)

Axillary (C5,C6)

Radial (C5-T1)

Lower Subscapular (C5,C6)

 

Note : However Ulnar Nerve near its origin, often receives a communicating branch from the lateral root of the median nerve originating from the lateral cord and carrying fibers from C7.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man, who is on treatment with ABVD regimen for Hodgkin’s lymphoma, presents to the OPD with complaints of increasing dyspnoea and nonproductive cough over the past several days. He was tachypneic and the x-ray showed bilateral lung infiltrates. Further workup pointed towards a diagnosis of pulmonary fibrosis. Which lobe of the lung would have been affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical history points towards the pulmonary fibrosis due to the use of bleomycin that causes lower lobe fibrosis. The patient is on bleomycin as a part of the ABVD regimen for Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

Pulmonary fibrosis is commonly seen with bleomycin. Bleomycin is degraded by an enzyme called hydrolase which is decreased in lungs and skin. Pulmonary toxicity begins with a dry cough, fine rales, and diffuse basal infiltrates on X-ray and may progress to life-threatening pulmonary fibrosis. No specific treatment is available to ameliorate the toxicity and managed by general symptomatic care. 

Related Pearl: Lobes involved in various lung diseases

Mnemonic to easily remember the lobe of lung involved in CTD is:

Upper Lobe - CHARTS

  • Coal workers pneumoconiosis (CWP), silicosis, berylliosis
  • Histiocytosis X (LCH)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis, ABPA
  • Radiation
  • Tuberculosis
  • Sarcoidosis

Lower lobes - RAIDS

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Asbestosis
  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) and non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
  • Drugs: bleomycin, busulfan, amiodarone, methotrexate, nitrofurantoin
  • Scleroderma

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought to the clinic with complaints of intermittent gross hematuria for the past 2 days. The boy had pain in the left flank region along with left testicular pain. Which of the following marked structure is affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards the diagnosis of nutcracker syndrome, in which the left renal vein is affected. In the above image, the structure marked as 'c' is the left renal vein as it lies anterior to the aorta and posteroinferior to the superior mesenteric artery.

Nutcracker syndrome: The compression of the left renal vein between the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric artery appears in the sagittal plane as if a nutcracker is crushing a nut (left renal vein). This condition is also called left renal vein entrapment syndrome.

Clinical presentation:

  • The most common clinical manifestation is intermittent macroscopic haematuria. Repeated episodes of gross haematuria and left flank pain are present.
  • Since the left gonadal vein drains via the left renal vein it may also result in left testicular pain in men or left lower quadrant pain in women.
  • Nausea and vomiting can result due to compression of the splanchnic veins.
  • In some cases, it is characterized by left renal vein hypertension secondary to compression and has been associated with haematuria and varicocele in children.

questions.text: The superior mesenteric artery lies anterior to which of the following structures of the pancreas?
questions.solution:
The superior mesenteric artery lies anterior to the uncinate process of the pancreas, which is marked as 'A' in the given image.

The superior mesenteric artery arises from the abdominal aorta. It lies first behind the body of the pancreas and then it moves forward and lies anterior to the uncinate process.

Other markings:

B-Head of pancreas

C-Tail of pancreas

D-Body of pancreas

questions.text: The given image shows the sagittal section of the left kidney in which structure 'A' is anterior to the structure 'B'. Identify the true statement.
questions.solution:
The left gonadal vein drains into the renal vein (marked as 'A') while the right gonadal vein drains into the inferior vena cava.

The renal veins are large-caliber vessels, which lie anterior to the renal arteries.

The hilum of the kidney contains the following structures from anterior to posterior:

  • Renal vein (marked as 'A')
  • Renal artery (marked as 'B')
  • Renal pelvis

Clinical note: Because the left testicular vein enters the left renal vein at a 90° angle, flow is less laminar on left than on right. So left venous pressure > right venous pressure → varicocele more common on the left.

questions.text: The image shows the inferior surface of the liver. Which lobe of the liver marked below forms the superior boundary of the epiploic foramen?
questions.solution:
The caudate lobe of the liver forms the superior boundary of the epiploic foramen. The lobe marked as '3' in the above image represents the caudate lobe.

The caudate lobe is visible as a prominence on the inferior and posterior surfaces of the liver. It lies posterior to the porta hepatis and to its right is the groove for the inferior vena cava.

The caudate lobe of the liver has a portal blood supply and hepatic vein drainage independent of the remainder of the liver.

 Other markings:

1- Quadrate lobe

2- Left Lobe 

4- Right lobe 

Shown below are 2 views of the visceral surface of the liver -

The epiploic foramen (foramen of Winslow or aditus to the lesser sac):

  • It forms the communication between the lesser sac and the greater sac.
  • The roof is formed by the caudate process of the liver
  • The floor is formed by the superior part of the duodenum
  • The posterior wall is the peritoneum covering the subhepatic part of the inferior vena cava
  • The anterior wall is a free edge of lesser omentum containing a bile duct, portal vein, and hepatic artery.
  • It serves as a site for an internal hernia.

Related Pearl: Relations of epiploic foramen and lesser sac

Relations of epiploic foramen:

Anterior
  • Hepatoduodenal ligament containing hepatic artery, portal vein, and common bile duct

Posterior
  • Inferior vena cava
  • Right suprarenal gland
  • Body of T12 vertebra

Superior
  • Caudate lobe of the liver

Inferior
  • 1st part of duodenum

 

Relations of lesser sac:

Anterior
  • Caudate lobe of liver
  • Lesser omentum
  • Stomach
  • First 2 layers of the greater omentum

Posterior

Structures forming the stomach bed:

  • Pancreas
  • Splenic artery
  • Left kidney and suprarenal gland
  • Commencement of abdominal aorta and coeliac artery
  • Left crus of the diaphragm
  • Splenic flexure of the colon
  • Transverse mesocolon

Superior
  • Reflection of the peritoneum from the esophagus to the diaphragm

Inferior
  • Continuation of 2nd and 3rd layers of the greater omentum

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

Left lateral sections

Segment II, III

questions.text: The tendons of a muscle are marked as '?' in the given image. Which of the following categories does this muscle belong to?
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the above image is the extensor digitorum longus muscle as it divides into four slips which run forwards on the dorsum of the foot and are inserted into the second and third phalanges of the four lesser toes. It is a unipennate muscle with oblique fibers.

Muscles with oblique fibers are subclassified as follows:

  • Triangular: They are triangular in shape. E.g., temporalis, adductor longus, trapezius
  • Pennate: They are feather-shaped. Based on their complexity, they can have the following subtypes:
    • Unipennate: Fascicles on one side of the tendon. E.g., flexor pollicis longus, extensor digitorum longus, peroneus tertius, and, palmar interossei
    • Bipennate: Fascicles on two sides of the tendon. E.g., rectus femoris, peroneus longus, flexor hallucis longus, and dorsal interossei
    • Multipennate: Central tendon branches into two or more branches within the muscle. E.g., deltoid, subscapularis
    • Circumpennate (radial): Muscle fibers converge to a central tendon in a radial fashion. E.g., tibialis anterior

Related Pearl: Classification of muscles according to their shape/direction of muscle fibers

Muscles with parallel fasciculi

Muscles with oblique fasciculi

Muscles with spiral or twisted fasciculi

 

Quadrilateral: Thyrohyoid

Triangular: Temporalis, Adductor longus, 

Spiral: Pectoralis major, Latissimus dorsi, Supinator and Trapezius

Strap like: Sartorius, Sternohyoid

Unipennate: Extensor digitorum longus, Flexor pollicis longus, Peroneus tertius, Palmar interossei

Partially cruciate and partially spiral: Masseter, Adductor magnus, Sternoclediomastoid 

Strap like with tendinous intersections: Rectus abdominis

Bipennate: Rectus femoris, Flexor hallucis longus, Peroneus longus, Dorsal interossei

 

Fusiform: Biceps brachii, digastric

Multipennate: Deltoid, Subscapularis

  

 

Circumpennate: Tibialis anterior

questions.text: A 50-year-old hypertensive patient was brought to the medicine OPD with spontaneous and often continuous writhing movements of a hand, an arm, the neck, and the face suggestive of athetosis. Infarction in which of the following structures would be responsible for this movement disorder?
questions.solution:
The movement disorder described in this patient is athetosis. It results from infarction in globus pallidus, marked as 3 in the given image.

Lesions in the globus pallidus frequently lead to spontaneous and often continuous writhing movements of a hand, an arm, the neck, or the face. These movements are called athetosis.

The internal capsule separates the caudate nucleus and the thalamus from the putamen and the globus pallidus (which is placed more medially than the putamen).

Other marked structures include:

  • Caudate nucleus - 1
  • Thalamus - 2
  • Putamen - 4

Related Pearl: Site of Lesion of Movement Disorders

Movement disorder

Site of Lesion

Athetosis

 Globus pallidus

Chorea

Putamen, Caudate

Hemiballismus

Subthalamic Nucleus

Parkinsonism

Substantia Nigra

questions.text: Which of the following arteries passes through the sulcus marked by the red arrow in the below image?
questions.solution:
The sulcus marked by the red arrow in the above image is the coronary sulcus (atrioventricular groove) and the right coronary artery passes through this sulcus.

The right coronary artery arises from the anterior aortic sinus (right coronary sinus) of the ascending aorta. It passes anteriorly and descends vertically in the coronary sulcus between the right atrium and the right ventricle. On reaching the inferior margin, it turns posteriorly and continues in the sulcus on to the diaphragmatic surface and the base of the heart.

The diameter of the right coronary artery is less than that of the left coronary artery. The right conal artery is, usually the first branch of the right coronary artery.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the boundaries of the foramen marked as 'A' in the given image?
questions.solution:
The epiploic foramen is marked as 'A' in the given image. It is related posteriorly to the inferior vena cava, right suprarenal gland, and body of the T12 vertebra.

The epiploic foramen (foramen of Winslow or aditus to the lesser sac) is a short vertical slit situated immediately posterior to the free margin of the lesser omentum. It is the entrance to the lesser sac from the greater sac. It measures about 3 cm in height in adults.

Boundaries of epiploic foramen are:

  • Anterior – Hepatoduodenal ligament containing hepatic artery, portal vein, and bile duct.
  • Posterior – T12 vertebra, inferior vena cava, right adrenal gland.
  • Superior – Caudate lobe of the liver.
  • Inferior – First part of the duodenum and the horizontal part of the hepatic artery.

Clinical note: Pringle maneuver (as shown below) is a technique where the free margin of the lesser omentum is compressed to obtain rapid control of the hepatic artery and portal vein in liver trauma and surgery.

Related Pearl: Relations of epiploic foramen and lesser sac

Relations of epiploic foramen:

Anterior
  • Hepatoduodenal ligament containing hepatic artery, portal vein, and common bile duct

Posterior
  • Inferior vena cava
  • Right suprarenal gland
  • Body of T12 vertebra

Superior
  • Caudate lobe of the liver

Inferior
  • 1st part of duodenum

 

Relations of lesser sac:

Anterior
  • Caudate lobe of liver
  • Lesser omentum
  • Stomach
  • First 2 layers of the greater omentum

Posterior

Structures forming the stomach bed:

  • Pancreas
  • Splenic artery
  • Left kidney and suprarenal gland
  • Commencement of abdominal aorta and coeliac artery
  • Left crus of the diaphragm
  • Splenic flexure of the colon
  • Transverse mesocolon

Superior
  • Reflection of the peritoneum from the esophagus to the diaphragm

Inferior
  • Continuation of 2nd and 3rd layers of the greater omentum

questions.text: A patient with shoulder pain was examined and Yergason’s supination test was found to be positive. Which marked structure is likely to be the source of pain?
questions.solution:
The Yergason sign/test is also called the supination sign. A positive Yergason test indicates inflammation arising from the long head of the biceps which is marked as 'A' in the given image.

In this test, the elbow is flexed to 90 degrees and the forearm is pronated. The patient then attempts to supinate the forearm actively against resistance. This test is negative with a complete or partial tear of the supraspinatus tendon.

Anatomically greater tubercle faces laterally, and the lesser tubercle anteriorly. These tubercles are separated from each other by the intertubercular sulcus which transmits the tendon of the long head of the biceps.

questions.text: The nerve supply of the muscle marked as 'A' in the image below is:
questions.solution:
The muscle marked as 'A' in the above image is psoas minor and it is supplied by anterior rami of L1.

It lies anterior to psoas major, entirely within the abdomen.

questions.text: The structure labelled as 'A'  in the given image penetrates the pericardium at the level of _______.
questions.solution:
The structure labelled as 'A' in the given image is the superior vena cava and it penetrates the pericardium at the level of the sternal plane. The horizontal sternal plane passes through the intervertebral disc between the T4 and T5 posteriorly and manubriosternal joint at the level of the second coastal joint anteriorly.

This plane also signifies:

  • Separation of the superior mediastinum and inferior mediastinum
  • Superior limit of the pericardium
  • Bifurcation of the pulmonary trunk
  • Origin of the arch of the aorta
  • The entry of the superior vena cava into the pericardium

questions.text: The image  below shows the gross specimen of the tongue. Which of the following papillae are present in the area marked as 'A'?
questions.solution:
The area marked as A in the above image is a V-shaped row and it has circumvallate papillae.

The papillae are arranged in a V-shaped row immediately in front of the sulcus terminalis on the dorsal surface of the tongue. The tongue is divided into anterior two-thirds, within the mouth, and posterior third, in the oropharynx by the sulcus terminalis.

  • Filiform papillae: They are minute cylindrical or conical projections that are mainly present on the dorsal part of the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue.
  • Fungiform papillae: They are large, rounded, and red in color and are mainly present on the lingual margins and also on the dorsal surface of the tongue.
  • Foliate papillae: They red, leaf-like mucosal ridges which are present bilaterally in two zones at the sides of the tongue near the sulcus terminalis.
  • Circumvallate papillae: They are large cylindrical structures that are around 8-12 in number. They are arranged in a V-shaped row immediately in front of the sulcus terminalis (not on the sides of the tongue).

Sulcus terminalis divides the tongue into anterior and posterior parts. The anterior or the oral part faces superiorly and the posterior or the pharyngeal part faces posteriorly.

questions.text: The following image depicts the dissection of the forearm. Identify the structure marked by the '?'.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above image is the anterior interosseous artery. It leaves the anterior compartment of the forearm just proximal to the pronator quadratus muscle as seen in the image. It piercs the interosseous membrane (lying below the pronator quadratus muscle) to reach the posterior compartment where it anastomoses with the posterior interosseous artery.

The anterior interosseous artery arises from the common interosseous artery and descends on the anterior aspect of the interosseous membrane with the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve. 

Pronator quadratus is a flat quadrilateral shaped muscle, that extends across the front of the distal ends of the radius and ulna. The muscle is supplied by the anterior interosseus artery and causes the pronation of the forearm.

questions.text: The cadaveric image shows the structures seen in the retroperitoneum, while the red arrow represents the uncinate process of the pancreas. Which of the following marked structure is involved in Gerhardt’s sign?
questions.solution:
Pulsations of the spleen detected in the presence of splenomegaly is called Gerhardt’s sign which is seen in aortic regurgitation. The spleen is marked as 'D' in the given image.

Spleen is just lateral to the left kidney.

Related Pearl: Different signs in Aortic Regurgitation

Sign

Description

De Musset's sign

  Head nodding with each heartbeat

Collapsing/Water Hammer/Corrigan pulse

 It is a bounding pulse with rapid upstroke  and descent

Lighthouse sign

  Alternate flushing & blanching of the forehead

Landolfi’s sign

  Alternating constriction and dilation of the pupil

Becker’s sign

  Retinal artery pulsations

Quincke’s pulse

 Alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail
Rosenbach’s sign  Pulsation of liver
Gerhardt’s sign  Pulsation over the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly

Traube’s sign

 A pistol shot sound over femoral arteries

Durozeiz’s sign

 To-and-fro murmur over the femoral artery when lightly compressed with a stethoscope

Hill’s sign

 The systolic blood pressure of the lower limb exceeds that of the upper limb at least by 20mm Hg

Muller’s sign

Systolic pulsation of the uvula

questions.text: The image below shows the dissection of the right side of the neck, and the red arrow denotes the right subclavian artery. What is not true about the structure labeled as A?

choices.text: It arises mainly from C4 spinal nerve.
The right side nerve is shorter than the left.
It is formed at the lateral border of scalenus anterior.
It is purely a motor nerve.

questions.solution:
The structure labeled as A is the right phrenic nerve, and it is a mixed nerve (sensory and motor nerve).

 It is derived mostly from the C4 ramus and also receives contributions from the C3 and C5 ventral rami. It is formed at the lateral border of scalenus anterior.

At the root of the neck, the right phrenic nerve runs anterior to the second part of the right subclavian artery from which it is seperated by scalenus anterior muscle. The phrenic nerve lies posterior to the right subclavian vein.

Right phrenic nerve is shorter and more vertical than the left.

Each phrenic nerve provides the sole motor supply to its hemidiaphragm. In its thoracic course, each phrenic nerve supplies sensory branches to the central parts of the diaphragm.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the areas marked in the given image?

choices.text: A is a type of association fiber
C is content of interpeduncular fossa
D is devoid of blood brain barrier

questions.solution:
A is anterior commissure, which is a type of commissural fiber, not association fiber.

B is lamina terminalis

C is the mamillary body and is a content of interpeduncular fossa.

D is the pineal gland, which does not have blood-brain barrier.

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: In individuals with a history of substance abuse and addiction, the marked structure is believed to trigger cravings on exposure to environmental cues. Which of the following is not true about the structure?

choices.text: It forms the base of the sylvian cistern
It lies between the frontal and temporal lobe
It receives somatosensory inputs from the entire body

questions.solution:
The structure marked by the arrow is the insular lobe. The insular cortex is not entirely agranular. The posterior part of the insular cortex is granular and the anterior part is agranular.

The insula forms the base of the Sylvian cistern and lies between the frontal and temporal lobes. It receives somatosensory, viscerosensory, homeostatic, and nociceptive information from the entire body. It receives inputs from the thalamus.

questions.text: Which of the following vessels is commonly injured in supracondylar fracture of the humerus?
questions.solution:
The brachial artery which is marked as '3' in the above image is commonly injured in supracondylar fracture of the humerus. The brachial artery is closely related to the median nerve; both move from the medial side of the arm to the anterior aspect of the elbow. 

When there is vascular injury, the patient may have paraesthesia or numbness in the fingers. On examination, the injured limb will be cold, may look pale or cyanosed, and the pulse is weak or absent.

A radiograph will reveal the fracture. An angiogram or duplex scan should be performed immediately if a vascular injury is suspected.

Related Pearl: Orthopedic trauma and associated vascular injuries

Injuries Vessel involved
Dislocations:
Shoulder dislocation Axillary
Posterior dislocation of the elbow Brachial
Hip dislocation Femoral
Knee dislocation Popliteal
Fractures:
Fracture proximal humerus Axillary
Supracondylar fracture humerus Brachial
Fracture both bones forearm Anterior interosseous artery
First rib fracture Subclavian
Pelvic fracture Presacral and internal iliac
Fracture femur Femoral
Supracondylar fracture femur Popliteal
Proximal tibial fracture Popliteal or its branches
Ankle injuries Posterior tibial

questions.text: The structure marked in the image connects________

choices.text: Orbital surfaces of the temporal lobes
Orbital surfaces of the frontal lobes

questions.solution:
The structure marked as 'A' is the splenium of the corpus callosum.

The body of the corpus callosum arches posteriorly and ends as the thickened posterior portion called the splenium. The fibers of the splenium form the forceps major, they arch backward into the occipital lobe (striate cortex) and connect the occipital lobes of both sides.

In terms of its anatomical arrangement from anterior to posterior, the corpus callosum consists of four distinct sections: the rostrum, genu, body, and splenium. These sections are responsible for linking specific areas of the cerebral cortex. The isthmus denotes the narrow region situated between the body and splenium at the posterior end of the corpus callosum.

Fibers originating from the genu cross over and give rise to the forceps minor, which establishes connections between frontal cortical regions. The fibers of the body traverse horizontally through the cerebral cortex, forming the corona radiata and other significant white matter pathways. Lastly, the rostral fibers facilitate connections between the orbital regions of the frontal lobes.

Related Pearl: Corpus Callosum

Parts of the corpus callosum:

  • Rostrum: connects frontal lobes (eg: orbitofrontal cortex)
  • Genu: connects frontal lobes. It is the anterior-most part.
  • Trunk or Body: connects temporal lobes.
  • Splenium: connects the two occipital lobes. It is the thickest part.

Note: Isthmus is a part which separates the body from splenium, some books mention it as a part.

  • The fibers of the genu curve forward into frontal lobes and form forceps minor.
  • The fibers of the trunk extend laterally as radiation of corpus callosum.
  • The fibers from the trunk and the splenium which form the lateral wall of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle constitute the tapetum.
  • The fibers from the splenium arching backwards into the occipital lobe form forceps major.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked by the red arrow in the given image?
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the masseter muscle and is innervated by the mandibular nerve (masseteric branch of the anterior trunk).

It can be identified as masseter, as the parotid duct with a part of the parotid gland and the branches of the facial nerve lie superficial to the muscle.

The muscle originates in three layers from the zygomatic bone and inserts into the ramus of the mandible. Its action is to elevate the mandible resulting in occlusion of the teeth, thereby aiding mastication.
